keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for Trump’s Gaza ceasefire deal despite its international recognition.
Trump’s overall approval rating has declined to a low point, with 61% disapproving in a recent poll.
Public approval of Trump’s economic policies has dropped significantly, with 62% disapproving of his inflation and cost-of-living handling.
Americans are increasingly pessimistic about the economy, with only 32% expecting economic improvement in the next year and 31% expecting wage increases.
Employed Americans are increasingly worried about job loss, with only 52% saying they are not at all concerned.
Foreign policy issues, including the Gaza deal, are low on Americans' priority list — only 4% consider international events the most important issue.
The public believes Trump has not done enough to lower prices, indicating economic concerns outweigh foreign policy concerns.
The Gaza deal, once seen as a major victory, has not translated into strong public support, especially amid rising regional tensions and economic anxieties.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the international recognition of a Gaza ceasefire deal brokered by President Donald Trump, Americans show little enthusiasm for the agreement. Public opinion polling indicates that Trump’s approval ratings remain low, with his overall approval at a record low of 37% and strong disapproval at 61%. The article suggests that Americans’ negative views of Trump are rooted not in foreign policy but in his economic record—particularly concerning inflation, the cost of living, and job security. Even though the Gaza deal was seen by some as a major diplomatic win, it has not translated into public support, especially when compared to the growing economic pessimism, with only 32% of Americans expecting economic improvement in the next year. This reflects a broader public sentiment that domestic economic issues are far more important than international diplomacy, with only 4% of Americans considering international events the most pressing national issue.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
